input:
2. A 7-year-old girl comes to the neurology clinic with a visible, soft swelling on her upper back at around the T3 level, noticed soon after birth but recently increasing in size and redness. Her parents report difficulty with walking, frequent tripping, and reduced sensation in her legs, alongside occasional muscle spasms. She also has chronic constipation and urinary urgency, indicating possible neurogenic bladder dysfunction. On examination, there is a cystic sac covered by thin, friable skin, with decreased lower limb strength and reduced proprioception bilaterally below the lesion. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk in the legs with clonus, and she has a positive Babinski reflex. MRI reveals a defect in the posterior elements of the upper thoracic spine with herniation of spinal cord and meninges through the vertebral defect consistent with upper thoracic spina bifida aperta. The child was born at term, and prenatal ultrasounds did not identify the lesion. Surgical closure of the defect is scheduled urgently to reduce infection risk, alongside initiation of physiotherapy and urological management.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I need to explain my symptoms clearly but simply, feeling a bit worried and overwhelmed, especially since this is all new and kind of confusing for me. I want to be honest but also not scare the doctor too much, so I will mention what I notice and how I feel physically and emotionally.

ANSWER: I’m here because I have this bump on my back that’s gotten a little bigger and red lately. I also feel like I can’t walk properly anymore, and my legs sometimes feel funny or weak, and I trip a lot. Sometimes I feel something in my tummy and wanna go to the bathroom suddenly.

input: 2. A 7-year-old girl comes to the neurology clinic with a visible, soft swelling on her upper back at around the T3 level, noticed soon after birth but recently increasing in size and redness. Her parents report difficulty with walking, frequent tripping, and reduced sensation in her legs, alongside occasional muscle spasms. She also has chronic constipation and urinary urgency, indicating possible neurogenic bladder dysfunction. On examination, there is a cystic sac covered by thin, friable skin, with decreased lower limb strength and reduced proprioception bilaterally below the lesion. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk in the legs with clonus, and she has a positive Babinski reflex. MRI reveals a defect in the posterior elements of the upper thoracic spine with herniation of spinal cord and meninges through the vertebral defect consistent with upper thoracic spina bifida aperta. The child was born at term, and prenatal ultrasounds did not identify the lesion. Surgical closure of the defect is scheduled urgently to reduce infection risk, alongside initiation of physiotherapy and urological management.Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, how they've changed over time, and if there are any other issues you've noticed that concern you?
output: Um, well, she’s had the swelling on her back since she was little, but it’s been getting bigger and more red lately. She’s been tripping more and having trouble walking, and she sometimes feels numb in her legs. I’m really worried because she also has trouble with going to the bathroom and constipation. It’s been like this for a while, but it feels like it’s worse now. Sometimes she has muscle spasms, and I just feel scared about what’s going on.

input: 2. A 7-year-old girl comes to the neurology clinic with a visible, soft swelling on her upper back at around the T3 level, noticed soon after birth but recently increasing in size and redness. Her parents report difficulty with walking, frequent tripping, and reduced sensation in her legs, alongside occasional muscle spasms. She also has chronic constipation and urinary urgency, indicating possible neurogenic bladder dysfunction. On examination, there is a cystic sac covered by thin, friable skin, with decreased lower limb strength and reduced proprioception bilaterally below the lesion. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk in the legs with clonus, and she has a positive Babinski reflex. MRI reveals a defect in the posterior elements of the upper thoracic spine with herniation of spinal cord and meninges through the vertebral defect consistent with upper thoracic spina bifida aperta. The child was born at term, and prenatal ultrasounds did not identify the lesion. Surgical closure of the defect is scheduled urgently to reduce infection risk, alongside initiation of physiotherapy and urological management.Can you describe how these symptoms — like the weakness, numbness, or any other sensations — affect your daily life and if there are specific activities or times when they worsen or improve?
output: Um, I feel kinda funny in my legs sometimes, like they get really heavy or tingly, and it's hard to walk straight or tripping a lot. When I try to run or play for a long time, I get more tired and my legs feel worse. Sometimes, I just can't feel things in my feet properly, and that makes me nervous.

input: 2. A 7-year-old girl comes to the neurology clinic with a visible, soft swelling on her upper back at around the T3 level, noticed soon after birth but recently increasing in size and redness. Her parents report difficulty with walking, frequent tripping, and reduced sensation in her legs, alongside occasional muscle spasms. She also has chronic constipation and urinary urgency, indicating possible neurogenic bladder dysfunction. On examination, there is a cystic sac covered by thin, friable skin, with decreased lower limb strength and reduced proprioception bilaterally below the lesion. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk in the legs with clonus, and she has a positive Babinski reflex. MRI reveals a defect in the posterior elements of the upper thoracic spine with herniation of spinal cord and meninges through the vertebral defect consistent with upper thoracic spina bifida aperta. The child was born at term, and prenatal ultrasounds did not identify the lesion. Surgical closure of the defect is scheduled urgently to reduce infection risk, alongside initiation of physiotherapy and urological management.Can you tell me how these symptoms have been affecting your daily activities, such as walking, balance, or managing your bladder and bowel habits, and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
output: Um, I think I trip a lot when I walk, and sometimes I feel like I can't keep my legs steady, like they’re not really following me. My bladder feels like it's urgent a lot, and I have to go more often, but sometimes it doesn’t feel like I can control it. I’ve noticed that when I sit for a long time or try to run, it gets worse. Nothing really makes it better, but I guess lying down for a bit sometimes helps, I don’t know.

Surgical closure of the defect is scheduled urgently to reduce infection risk, alongside initiation of physiotherapy and urological management.Have you noticed any recent fever, chills, or signs of infection around the lesion? Also, can you describe whether your neurological symptoms—such as weakness, numbness, or sensations—have been gradually worsening or if they come and go?
output: I don’t think she’s had a fever or anything like that, but I did notice her skin around the swelling looks a little more red and warm sometimes. She’s been tripping more and says her legs feel kind of weird, like they don’t move quite right, but I don’t know if that’s gotten worse or not.

output: No, I don’t think I’ve had any fevers or chills. But sometimes I feel pretty tired, and I do get those weird kind of sweating at night, but I don’t know if that’s really the same.

Also, have you experienced any worsening of your symptoms such as increased weakness, new numbness, or loss of control over bladder or bowels?
output: Um, yes, sometimes it gets more red or warm around the thing on my back, and I feel a little funny in my legs like they’re weaker or won’t move right. I also worry about calling to the bathroom because it feels different lately.

output: Um, I think my legs feel a little more weird, like they don't move right sometimes, and I feel like I can't hold my pee as good as before. The spot on my back is sticking out more and it looks redder and kind of warm, I guess. But I don’t know if that means anything.

output: Um, yeah, I think they do feel a little different sometimes, especially when I run or jump. My legs feel funny or sort of weak, and I get tired more easily, I guess. It’s been kind of like that lately.
